title: Wednesday, 28th October, 2015

11:02 am
PM

Semi desert area in South Africa

PM

I share it, because of this...

PM

As you will see from the formal notice of meeting which follows this letter, shareholders will be asked to
consider and, if deemed appropriate, to approve a resolution to change the name of the Company to
"Karoo Energy plc". The rationale for the change of name stems from the Company's change in focus.
The Company initially aimed to invest in a portfolio of companies within the oil and gas exploration sector,
the "nodding donkey" being the symbol synonymous with onshore oil production. Given that the Company
is now focused on gas exploration only with the intention of becoming an electricity producer, the
"nodding donkey" would not adequately represent the Company's current approach. Further to the award
of its shale gas exploration licences and coal bed methane licences in Botswana, the Company is now
focussed on exploring opportunities in Southern Africa. The Karoo is the semi-desert natural region of
Southern Africa, whilst the Karoo Supergroup is the most widespread stratigraphic unit in Africa south of
the Sahara Desert, and the Board believes that the proposed name better reflects the Company's primary
focus, being the exploration of gas in Southern Africa.

PM

We provisionally think that the retail mobile market in the UK, with four main mobile providers and a substantial number of smaller operators, is competitive. As BT is a smaller operator in this market, it is unlikely that the merger will have a significant effect on competition. By the same token, it is unlikely that the merger will have a significant effect on competition in the retail broadband market, where EE is only a minor player in that market."
"We have also been looking at the ways in which, as a merged company, BT/EE might try to disadvantage competitors which it supplied with services such as backhaul, wholesale mobile or wholesale broadband services. We have provisionally found that in some areas it is unlikely that they would have both the ability and incentive to do so - and in others that the effects of their attempting to do so would be limited.
Having considered all the evidence, the group does not provisionally believe that, in a dynamic and evolving sector, it is more likely than not that BT/EE will be able to use its position to damage competition or the interests of consumers.

PM

John Wotton, inquiry chair

11:09 am

BE

Here's Morgan Stanley.

BE

Provisional approval: The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) this
morning announced that it has provisionally approved BT’s acquisition of EE,
unconditionally without remedies. The CMA has said it has provisionally
decided that the acquisition “is not expected to result in a substantial lessening
of competition (SLC) in any market in the UK”. These include the supply of
retail mobile, wholesale mobile, mobile backhaul, wholesale broadband and
retail fixed broadband services. We previously wrote (see BT - Navigating
through the regulatory noise) that a combined BT-EE may have to offer
concessions such as disposal of spectrum or enhanced MVNO terms to receive
regulatory approval.
Key extracts from the CMA's press release: The CMA comments that BT and
EE "operate largely in separate areas". "After looking in detail at different
markets - including the supply of retail mobile, wholesale mobile, mobile
backhaul, wholesale broadband and retail fixed broadband services - the group
has provisionally decided that the merger is not expected to result in a
substantial lessening of competition (SLC) in any market in the UK". There was
some concern on wholesale access to the mobile market (ie MVNO access)
where the investigation group were equally divided, but findings of SLC
require a two thirds majority.

11:09 am
BE

the final approval process. Thereafter, closure of the EE acquisition should take
place shortly thereafter. BT still expects the deal to close within the financial
year to the end of March 2016.
BT-EE would be a powerful combination: A combined BT-EE would create
the largest convergent operator enabling BT to leverage EE's retail stores to
cross sell its broadband, TV and sports packages. EE delivered strong H1
results growing adjusted EBITDA by +9% YoY. BT targets annual opex and
capex synergies from the transaction of £360mn pa.
Trading multiples: Fully incorporating BT's synergy targets, BT would trade
on a 7.8% FCFE yield post pension payments or 8.4% pre pension. This
compares to the sector's 2017 FCFE yield of 6.7%. BT reports Q2 results
tomorrow.

BE

PM

11:12 am
BE

As in, https://www1.relish.net/athome

BE

.... Let me see if there's any more sellside. Merrill, perhaps.

BE

CMA provisional approval is a positive
The CMA has announced its view this morning that the BT/EE merger should be cleared
without remedies. The CMA found no substantial lessening of competition (SLC) in
relation to any of the markets (retail & wholesale mobile, mobile backhaul, retail and
wholesale broadband). The CMA investigated the 10 Theories of Harm it identified in
July; 20 submissions from third parties were reviewed and 10 hearings conducted.
New timeline: responses by 19th Nov, full decision by 18th Jan
A full report on the provisional findings will be published later this week. Responses are
welcome by 19th November. The CMA has also extended its deadline for a final report by
8 weeks to 18th January in order to take full and proper account of submissions. We
expect deal closure shortly after = payment to DT/Orange and consolidation. Any final
decision can be challenged in the Court of Appeal, but we think this is unlikely.
No SLC across all markets, unanimous decision in all but one
The CMA was unanimous in finding no SLC in all but one market. - wholesale mobile.
Here the 4 person committee was split 50:50. In the larger summary report on the case
website outlining the CMA’s thoughts, SLC in wholesale mobile was considered possible
in a world where mobile becomes a driver of bundle purchases. The overall view was
that the other three MNOs offer credible wholesale competition. In our opinion, it is
unlikely that the findings across all markets change. The CMA’s points are well reasoned
and EE’s incentive to disadvantage wholesale mobile customers appears limited in a
world where mobile is usually secondary to fixed in the bundle. Interestingly vertical
integration of BT inc ownership of Openreach is not seen as an issue which Ofcom will
undoubtedly take into account in its Strategic Review due early 2016.

11:14 am
BE

We rate BT a Buy, PO 600p
As argued in BT: Adding to Europe 1: Transformation continues, regulatory headwinds
diminishing (121015) we believe through the acquisition of EE, BT will transform into a
converged operator which will drive sustainable revenue and EBITDA growth and
therefore earnings ahead of current consensus estimates. Quad play/bundling are
nascent in the UK but BT is well positioned to take a leading share in this segment as
BT: i) can leverage its large portfolio of unregulated street furniture to deploy small cells
ii) drives cross sell with a #1 share in broadband and unrivalled ability to use femtocell
offload iii) has #1 or combined 45% of total UK mobile spectrum allowing EE to offer
LTE at best possible speeds with full coverage. Next datapoint Q2s 29th Oct.

BE

Here's Charlie Mills at Credit Suisse

BE

Who, it occurs, has the specialist areas of sugar and tobacco. He's a one-man health hazard.

BE

■ We raise our EPS estimates by 1% and our price target to £41, rating
remains Outperform
■ Q3 trading was certainly stronger than we and the market had, with volumes
+0.4% after -2.9% at H1, Europe the stand-out feature at +1%, though the
+6.4% in EEMEA was also considerably better than we expected.
■ Importantly for tobacco, pricing was very strong (+7.4%), up 200bps from H1,
though Q3 was a soft comparator and the group highlights that Q4 is
expected to be lower.
■ With robust pricing, a strong performance from the Global Drive Brands (up
7% on 9 months), and no change to the transactional impact of FX (still -6%),
we see no reason why margins won’t be up for the year (albeit modestly).
■ Though the translational impact of FX was raised this was already in our
estimates, so our 1% increase in EPS reflects a better organic performance.
■ The Court ruling in Canada requiring BAT to put CS$750m in escrow ahead
of a resolution of the original ruling (which the industry has appealed) is a
disappointing addendum, but maybe itself subject to appeal.
■ Valuation: The disproportionate rise in our price target versus EPS change
reflects the continued strength in the ITC and Reynolds share prices. These
two Associates now trade on 24x and 22x 2016E earnings respectively.
While BAT may trade on 17x 2016E, the operations (i.e. ex the Associates)
are on only 15x, a significant discount to Staples. Tobacco remains our
preferred subsector, and the trading backdrop confirms that.

11:20 am
BE

And Deutsche.

BE

Strong fundamentals
Successful investing in Staples is about identifying the serial compounders (of which BAT is one of the strongest in our view), backing them over the long-term and avoiding the noise of quarterly reporting. With the quarter BAT has just delivered, that is easier said than done (volumes. more so than price/mix (supported by pricing against weak EM currencies)). The strong operational momentum from the HY continued: 9M cigarette share +40bps in key markets (HY +40bps); Global Drive Brands vols. +7.2% (HY +6.0%, Q3 +9.7%); 9M GDB share +100bps. Rothmans was again the major contributor to GDB growth. In addition, we note Reynolds American (c22% of pro-forma BAT EPS, yesterday reported Q3 in-line with market expectations (EPS 55 cents), narrowing FY EPS guidance higher from $1.90-$2.00 to $1.94-$2.00.

BE

FX and forecasts
In part, as the corollary of strong price/mix, BAT has revised the negative impact of FX on operating profit to -6% transactional and -12% translation equating to a -10% FY EPS hit vs. HY guidance of -8%. In addition, we note Q4 price/mix is a more difficult comp and BAT will be investing additional resource into next generation products in Q4. While adopting the revised FX guidance we are conscious of the margin potential in the business (£120m of negative transactional FX absorbed at the HY) and the strong Q3: can’t help thinking we may be too conservative in taking c1% of our EPS forecasts.

11:20 am
BE

Quebec litigation update
Last night, BAT’s Canadian subsidiary, Imperial Tobacco Canada (ITCAN), was ordered to pay C$758m (c£375m) in quarterly installments (C$108m Dec. ’15 to June ’17) into escrow to satisfy a court order that the defendants to the Quebec action provide security to the plaintiffs in regard to the plaintiff’s costs. Noting BAT plc is not a defendant, ITCAN intends to review its options.
Outlook
The Canadian news warranted comment because it is new; but for little other reason. The fundamentals of the business (higher share; GDB growth; pricing power; margin upside; well invested next generation products; exposure to growth markets; highly regarded management) culminating in a very strong Q3 performance, albeit tempered by FX, provides us with yet another data point highlighting BAT as one of the very best staples’ compounders. BUY.

BE

The Imperial Tobacco story seems to have gone quiet recently, incidentally.

BE

In spite of us running every possible combination up the flagpole at least once.

Let me put up some Campling at Aviate here. He's not exactly on the fence on this one.

BE

Key questions need answers to model out Hello Fresh. And these weren't disclosed at the CMD. Namely, what is the average churn rate and the life cycle of a subscriber at Hello Fresh? The company swerved giving answers claiming details couldn't be provided for competitive reasons and because the service was only for those with an "interesting lifestyle" (CEO Hello Fresh, Sept 2015). And in comparing the food subscription service as one which can be bigger/longer than a phone subscription is, frankly, mind boggling. Hello Fresh claim significant growth at scale. Face value (CMD stats while we await filing documentation) show €268m annualised sales (on Q2 revs x 4) and 429% YoY growth in active subscribers. However, these active subs include those receiving free boxes (4% of total) and those who cancelled subscriptions during the quarter (i.e. not very active). Hello Fresh also provide a range of 'pre-marketing' metrics. But this is somewhat disanalogous. After all marketing is some 30% of revenues for mature markets (Benelux) and likely double that in other markets.

11:40 am
Just Eat PLC (JE.:LSE): Last: 430.00, up 5.1 (+1.20%), High: 430.40, Low: 426.20, Volume: 347.25k
PM

Here's Earl's stuff

PM

Pursuant to today's warning by the US listed online restaurant order and delivery service, GrubHub (GRUB US, mkt cap $2.2 billion), I sold short a few Just Eat (JE/ LN, mkt cap £2.9 billion), the UK listed online restaurant order and delivery service.

This was not a difficult decision to make.

You may reckon that JE/ with its superior market capitalization to GRUB is as distinguished in terms of its prospective P&L. However, this is not the case.

11:40 am
PM

For sales:
GRUB is forecast* to achieve £237 million in sales in 2015, rising 29% to £305 million in 2016.

by contrast
JE/ is forecast* to achieve £235 million in sales in 2015, rising 34% to £315 million in 2016.

In terms of EBITDA and EBIT:
GRUB is expected* to deliver £72/44 million in EBITDA/EBIT in 2015, rising to £96/63 million EBITDA/EBIT in 2016.

while
JE/ is penciled* in for £55/48 million in EBITDA/EBIT in 2015, rising to £89/83 million in EBITDA/EBIT in 2016.

PM

The major difference between the two companies appears to be in valuation:
GRUB trades* on 40x this year's earnings, falling to 31x 2016. Or alternatively an EV/EBITDA multiple of 16.9x 2015 falling to 12.7x 2016.

as compared to
JE/ trading* on 76x this year's earnings, falling to 47x 2016. Or alternatively an EV/EBITDA multiple of 49x 2015 falling to 30x 2016.

*Bloomberg consensus

So what gives?
I reckon one set of valuations is wrong. US investor appetite would suggest it's Just Eat's.

BE

Yeah. It's not difficult to build a short case for Just Eat.

11:41 am
BE

Trickier is to build a long case, so congratulations to Jefferies, which has done exactly that this morning.

BE

For the sake of balance .........

BE

We raised FY15 numbers, 12 October, ahead of, what we expect to be a strong Q3 on 3 November, 3Q UK traffic growth appears very robust. Since then Domino's have pushed out strong 3Q numbers, covered below, and of course GRUB warned yesterday. We cover that too and discuss, briefly, how very different GRUB and JE are. To avoid any doubt, we expect JE to deliver positive 3Q news flow on the 3rd, another contrast to GRUB.

'execution...execution....'. We last wrote on JE on 12 October, upgrading our FY15 numbers for the third time this year and moving ahead of consensus, we look for FY15 revenue £249.4m, +58.9% YoY and adjusted EBITDA £59.6m, a 23.9% margin, 8% and 11% ahead of consensus respectively.

3Q15 UK traffic data, the driver. Analysing multiple sources of traffic data in the UK across the Just Eat platform, visit growth across 3Q appeared as high as +75% YoY and this dynamic excludes 'in app' activity. Our FY15 revenue forecast assumes a like for like order growth of c. +50% for 2H15, 1H15, +47%.

Reflecting on financials and a top-notch CFO. FY14 revenue +62.2%, £157.0m and 1H15 revenue +54.4%, £107.8m, JEF has upgraded numbers three times in 2015. Current FY15 guide, revenues 'around £230m', intuitively conservative it seems, though can +46.5% YoY growth be viewed as 'conservative'? CFO, Mike Wroe, despite the extremely high growth dynamic, has delivered financially and guided the market conservatively.

Domino's 3Q15 print, 14 October. A positive trading statement from Domino's, 'trading in our core UK business was particularly robust', 'driven by our continued investment in digital'. 75% of delivered sales YTD have been online, more than half placed through the app. 'The Board expects full year results to be ahead of its expectations'.

3Q15 GRUB print yesterday. A tough print for GRUB yesterday, the stock down +20% and weighing on JE.

GRUB printed 3Q15 revenues of US$85.7m versus the guided range of US$85m to US$87m. Coming towards the lower end of the range, GRUB referred to a number of business interruptions and outages in the quarter due to the transition to a shared technology platform between GrubHub/Seamless Web and due also to unfavourable weather, it being unusually dry and mild.

3Q15 adjusted EBITDA of US$21.5m versus the guided range of US$23m to US$25m. The miss put down to increased investment in the delivery proposition, GRUB acquired two delivery operations, DiningIn and Restaurants on the Run earlier this year for c.US$75m.

GRUB remain positive on the delivery proposition and the continuing investment reduced the FY15 adjusted EBITDA guide from US$104m-US$112m to US$101m-US$103m.

GRUB, arguably quite a different proposition to JE. Clearly both play in online takeaway, but the geographic overlap is zero, GRUB just US, JE not there. The US takeaway restaurant backdrop, diverse, but characterised by numerous 'heavy-lifting' franchise chains', the UK, incredibly fragmented, dominated by single premise owned and operated businesses. GRUB the result of the 2013 merger of Grub Hub and Seamless Web, still problematic clearly. In addition, GRUB's M&A has taken them forcefully into all things delivery. In contrast, JE pretty much geographic addition flavoured M&A and they do not, will not....do delivery on any real scale...GRUB buy, JE build. And lastly, consensus 14/17 adjusted EPS CAGR, prior to GRUB's miss, GRUB +35%, JE +48%, we expect the gap to widen as consensus comes down for GRUB. GRUB 0.8x PEG, JE 0.7x.

11:41 am
BE

You get the idea.

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 549.80, down 7.6 (-1.36%), High: 558.50, Low: 543.10, Volume: 3.63m
BE

And Petra's update, which warns on realised prices once again.

11:46 am
BE

Here's BMO to summarise.

BE

Petra has released its fiscal Q1/16 operational results, which were fairly mixed overall. During the quarter, the companyreported group diamond production of 843kcts, some 12% better than BMO Research’s forecast of 752kcts. The companydidn’t conduct any diamond sales during FQ1/16; however, post quarter-end, Petra completed its first tender for the financial year, yielding revenues of US$68.9M form sales of 697kcts at an average realised price of US$99/ct. At the end of the quarter, Petra reported a cash balance of US$57M, down from US$167M reported at the end of June 2015. The reduction in cash balance is largely attributable to diamond inventory build to US$103M (from US$34M) given the first tender was post quarter-end.

BE

(@TheLeggie: that's the one. Thank you.)

11:46 am
BE

Our View:

Mixed. The company reported a strong quarter in terms of production, largely attributable to Finsch, and reiteratedF2016 guidance of 3.3-3.4Mcts (BMO Research estimate 3.3Mcts).

On a negative note, Petra has indicated that realised prices at its first tender softened by ~9% compared with FQ4/15. Prices were impacted by a lower value mix from Finsch, Koffiefontain, and Kimberly, although this is in part offset by higher sales volumes.

With the transition into the new mining blocks at most of its South African operations, grades, production, and diamond values are expected to improve in H2/FY16. As such, at this stage, Petra has reiterated its realised price guidance for the year.

BE

So basically, Petra's doing nothing wrong in terms of its operations but is selling into a structurally awful market with no prospect of recovery.

Profitability in the third quarter has been impacted by mix, both across end markets and within the aftermarket following lower than anticipated spares volumes for older civil and military aircraft. Additionally, lower volumes and a number of programme deferrals announced by customers have also impacted margins. Energy markets continued to weaken, with the further organic decline resulting in lower than expected overhead absorption.

11:49 am
BE

Yup. Spares volumes suffering as well as contract deferrals.

PM

These factors are expected to persist through the fourth quarter, which will result in underlying operating profit for the year being meaningfully below the current company compiled consensus estimate of £369m. Free cash flow for the Group remains strong, although given the lower than expected profit outturn for 2015 this will result in financial gearing higher than the previously guided level of 2.1x net debt:EBITDA.

PM

PM

Weaker revenue growth… Having reported organic Civil OE and
Aftermarket growth of 4% and 5% respectively during 1H15, Meggitt reports
2% and 0% respectively for 3Q15 (MSe 5% for both in 2015). In Military,
Meggitt reports -2% in 3Q after +6% in 1H15 (MSe 5% for 2015), while in
Energy the material declines continue albeit at a slower rate, with -16% for 3Q
after -18% in 1H15 (MSe -19% for 2015), though Meggitt highlights
operational leverage issues, presumably at Heatric.
... with negative mix implications for profitability: In addition to lower
volumes and a number of programme deferrals by customers (e.g.
Bombardier), two mix effects are exacerbating the impact on profitability – a
shift away from high-margin aftermarket sales to lower-margin OE sales, and
then within aftermarket, lower than anticipated spares volumes for older civil
and military aircraft (in some instances due to early retirements, a step change
from the half year), which tend to be the most lucrative.
Other implications and actions being taken: Given certain timing and
other impacts, we would expect perhaps two-thirds of the downgrade on profit
to flow through to free cash (MSe £146m for 2015), resulting in a c.0.2x
increase in net debt/EBITDA this year (MSe 2.3x for 2015 on MS definition). To
mitigate some of the impact, Meggitt has said it is considering a further 300
redundancies – if confirmed, we would expect these to result in a c. £15m
exceptional charge in 2015, while saving £10-£11m annualised from 2016
onwards.

BE

Lloyds has reported Q3 results. We would characterize pre-tax results as inline
with a 17% miss in other income (read: fixed income, which was papered
over/poorly explained in the commentary) offset by better costs (5% beat) and
impairments. CET1 at 13.7% is already at our FY15 estimate and TBV grew 3%
QoQ despite £600m of conduct costs.
On the metrics...
NIM at 2.64% in Q3 v 2.62% H1 – consistent with our view for at worst a flat NIM in H2,
before rising in 2016. Company now guides to FY15 NIM of 2.63% (vs. guidance of 2.60%
previously), consistent with 9M margin (FY14: 2.64%, JEFe FY15: 2.61%, FY16: 2.66%).
Asset quality ratio of 0.11% for 9M15 and company guides that FY15 will be less than
0.15% (JEFe = 0.16%).
Loans increased 0.7% QoQ as company still growing less than the market in mortgage (net
growth 1% yoy), 'reflecting focus on margin'.
Costs: Underlying costs fell 9% QoQ, with the cost: income ratio falling 1.5ppt to 47.4%
in 3Q and consistent with management commitment to be aggressive on costs in a soft
revenue environment (we look for commentary on the conference call at 9.30am today as
to exactly where such cost efficiencies are coming from). Despite an increased bank levy in
Q4, Lloyds is still targeting an improvement in FY15 cost-income ratio (FY14 was 49.8%).
Capital: CET1 Ratio at 13.7% v 13.3% at 2Q (JEFe = 13.7% for FY15, so looks a bit better).
3Q CET1 Ratio includes a 20bps headwind from AFS movement.
TBV/share = 55.0p, up from 53.5p at Q2 and includes £500m of PPI charge & £100m of
other conduct costs. PPI charge does not reflect Oct. 2 FCA announcement.
Outlook: Lloyds is guiding that other income is expected to recover in Q4, but likely to be
down on 2014 (vs prior guidance for “broadly stable”), we suspect that this will be offset by
much better cost performance and impairments. Bottom line is that we don’t see estimates
moving up on these results, though capital return thesis intact and tangible book value
growth is currently annualising at 12%.

11:58 am
BE

Nomura also buying on weakness.

BE

Investment case from here
Lloyds has missed consensus largely owing to weaker other operating
income (OOI) driven by insurance and commercial banking. Reported NIMs
came in better than expected at 264bp in the quarter and in line with our
expectations. However, average interest earnings assets (AIEA) continues
to be lower than expected despite customer loans increasing, which
suggests underlying margin pressures.
Looking into 2016 we expect to see revenue downgrades to the tune of
GBP 400m-500m mainly owing to OOI. However, cost control was strong in
the quarter and asset quality continues to surprise, so most of this revenue
downgrade will be offset. Longer term estimates might see more of an
impact as consensus will look to normalise cost of risk, rather than pass on
the 3Q beat.
Lloyd’s investment case is driven by its potential dividend yield. With
distributable underlying earnings yield (including DTAs) at c12%, our longterm
expectation remains that Lloyds will deliver a top decile dividend yield
from current valuation in the long run. In this context, PPI costs falling to
GBP 0.6bn in 3Q14 from a 1H15 level of GBP 1.7bn will be seen as a
positive. CET1 ratio improved 40bp in the quarter to 13.7%. While weaker
than our expectation, it still underpins our 3.25p distribution expectation for
the year against consensus of 2.6p. We would find this a particularly good
buying opportunity on any weakness.

BE

Key points from the results
• NII came in at GBP 2,863m against consensus of GBP 2,937m. Reported
NIMs were better than expected at 9M15 level of 263bp or 3Q15 level of
264bp. However, AIEA fell 1% to GBP 438.7bn, while customer loans
grew 0.7% to GBP 455bn, so the denominator has helped report better
NIMs.
• Other operating income was the main source of weakness coming in at
GBP 1,374m against consensus of GBP 1,622m. The weakness is driven
by non-repeat of bulk annuity income and weak OOI in commercial
banking. This will be the main source of revenue downgrade looking into
2016-17.
• Cost control was evident in the quarter, coming in at GBP 2,108m against
consensus of GBP 2,240m, offsetting some of the revenue downgrades.
• Cost of risk came in better at GBP 157m against consensus of GBP 225m.
• CET1 at 13.7% is among best in the sector (ex Scandi) and will underpin
our above consensus 3.25p distribution expectation (consensus at 2.6p).
TBV grew by 2.8% to 55p.

PM

Jes Staley has been confirmed as the new CEO, starting on 1 Dec. This is as expected/signalled, but where the announcement could have been taken as an opportunity to reaffirm the commitment to the Investment Bank, Chair John McFarlane stated that the “re-positioning” of the Investment Bank is “one of our major priorities”. Staley’s statement that “we will be committed to preserving and enhancing the trust that is the foundation of Barclays’ reputation” stands out, and more to the point “the IB will adopt a less capital-intensive model” gives a clear indication of where the cuts will be made. We take these as positive signals (for radical restructuring). At 0.8x 2016E price/tangible book, little of this potential value creation is reflected in the valuation. Maintain Hold.
